DataElement.preferredName: Retroperitoneal Soft Tissue Sarcoma AJCC Edition 8 Pathologic Distant Metastasis M Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the distant metastasis for soft tissue sarcoma of the retroperitoneum based on clinical stage information combined with operative findings, and evidence obtained from pathology review when surgery is the first definitive therapy, using AJCC Ed. 8 criteria.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Retroperitoneum Soft Tissue Sarcoma Pathologic M Category
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The back of the abdomen where the kidneys lie and the great blood vessels run._A malignant neoplasm arising from muscle tissue, adipose tissue, blood vessels, fibrous tissue, or other supportive tissues excluding the bones._Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology._One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The back of the abdomen where the kidneys lie and the great blood vessels run.:A malignant neoplasm arising from muscle tissue, adipose tissue, blood vessels, fibrous tissue, or other supportive tissues excluding the bones.

Concepts.definition: The back of the abdomen where the kidneys lie and the great blood vessels run.
A malignant neoplasm arising from muscle tissue, adipose tissue, blood vessels, fibrous tissue, or other supportive tissues excluding the bones.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.origin: AJCC Based:Staging Criteria Based on American Joint Committee on Cancer System
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: TL released; 2/24/22.; 4-3-19 created for standardization; tmt.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Soft Tissue Sarcoma Retroperitoneum American Joint Committee on Cancer Edition 8 M Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A finding about one or more characteristics of soft tissue sarcoma of the retroperitoneum, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v8 classification system. This classification system applies to common sarcomas in the retroperitoneum. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)_A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
